review.title: The CARESSES EU-Japan project: making assistive robots culturally competent
review.abstract: The nursing literature shows that cultural competence is an important requirement for effective healthcare. We claim that personal assistive robots should likewise be culturally competent, that is, they should be aware of general cultural characteristics and of the different forms they take in different individuals, and take these into account while perceiving, reasoning, and acting. The CARESSES project is an Europe-Japan collaborative effort that aims at designing, developing and evaluating culturally competent assistive robots. These robots will be able to adapt the way they behave, speak and interact to the cultural identity of the person they assist. This paper describes the approach taken in the CARESSES project, its initial steps, and its future plans.

sections.heading: 4 Development methodology
sections.text: CARESSES follows a highly user-oriented methodology to develop relevant technological solutions, where requirements and knowledge come from end-users and domain experts, and validation is carried out on end-users. Research in the areas of Transcultural Care and Culturally Competent Health Care forms the theoretical basis of CARESSES and paves the way for the development of culturally competent robots. The robot's attitude towards users was initially created on the basis of available data on the dimensions of Hofstede [13], supplemented by specific information on the cultural group of users. This allowed preliminary assumptions about the expected behaviour of a culturally competent robot, described in terms of Cultural Awareness, Cultural Knowledge and Cultural Sensitivity [23].

sections.heading: 4.1 Initial scenarios
sections.text: In order to arrive at a number of technical requirements, we have based the above concepts on concrete examples summarised in Tables 1, 2 and 3, which describe possible scenarios of interaction between a culturally competent assistant robot and an elderly person. Scenarios are written by experts in transcultural care and refer to the fundamentals and actions of culturally competent caregivers. Each table reports on a pattern of sensorimotor and / or verbal interaction, the required robotic skills and cultural competence (in terms of cultural awareness, cultural knowledge and cultural sensitivity) that can help determine the robot's behavior.

sections.heading: 4.2 Elicitation of guidelines
sections.text: In order to base the assumptions on observations in real-life scenarios, the cultural competence of the robot is now undergoing a process of iterative refinement based on the cultural behaviors gathered from videotaped encounters between elderly people living in sheltered shelters and their caregivers. Once the relevant verbal and non-verbal behaviors have been identified and verified, an expert panel will refine the assumption and update the cultural competence of the robot prototype, taking great care to eliminate stereotypical notions [19]. This process will ultimately produce guidelines describing how culturally competent robots should behave in assistive scenarios. The knowledge acquired in all these steps, both through comprehensive literature reviews on the topics and through video recordings, will be formalized using tools for knowledge representation, since the availability of formal languages for the representation of knowledge forms the basis for enabling the robot to actualize autonomous ways of thinking, its planning, and ultimately its dependence on cultural capabilities in such contexts.

sections.heading: 5 Technical solutions
sections.text: From a technological point of view, the first step of CARESSES was to (i) identify the basic technical skills required for cultural competence and (ii) define a system architecture that will allow these skills to be integrated into a fully autonomous assistance robot that may be embedded in an intelligent environment.

sections.heading: 5.1 System architecture
sections.text: Figure 3 shows the main modules of the CARESSES architecture: the Cultural Knowledge Base, the Culturally-sensitive Planning & Execution, and the culturally-aware Human-Robot Interaction, which will be briefly described in the next sub-sections. All components will be integrated into universAAL [10], a software platform for open distributed systems that has emerged from a consolidation process within the framework of an EU project. The universal AAL platform enables the seamless integration of heterogeneous components within an environmental network by making full use of two basic concepts that prove to be very suitable for integrating components developed by different partners in a complex RTD project: (i) the use of ontologies to define the services of network nodes and the procedures and data formats for accessing such services; (ii) the use of three dedicated communication buses for theme-based communication between network nodes, namely a context bus and a user interface.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: Cultural competence enables assisted robots to be more acceptable by being more sensitive to the needs, habits and lifestyle of the user. In this article, we discussed the concept of cultural competition put forward in the context of the joint EU-Japan project CARESSES. We gave an overview of the project, discussed the problems it has to solve, discussed its methodology and outlined its first steps. To our knowledge, CARESSES is the first attempt to build culturally competent robots. We believe that cultural competence is a necessary, hitherto insufficiently studied component for any social, personal or assistive robot. In this regard, we are convinced that CARESSES is a ground-breaking project. Even though CARESSES only produces a prototype that needs to be further evaluated and refined before we can assess the impact of our pilot studies on reliability with regard to the final evaluation of robots.
